nodes.text: Major infrastructure projects systematically produce biased ex ante forecasts of costs and benefits that lead to persistent cost overruns, benefit shortfalls, and a 'survival of the un-fittest' outcome; remedy requires outside-view forecasting plus governance reforms
Major infrastructure projects have long planning horizons, complex interfaces, nonstandard technology, multi-actor decision making, scope changes, lock-in, and weak contingency provisions
Empirical database for transportation projects shows large, persistent inaccuracies in cost and demand forecasts across project types, nations, and decades

Statistical results: average cost overruns â€” rail 44.7%, bridges and tunnels 33.8%, roads 20.4%; 9 out of 10 projects have cost overrun; large standard deviations; rail passenger traffic on average 51.4% lower than forecast
Because forecasts of costs and benefits are biased and inaccurate, conventional ex ante cost-benefit analyses for major projects are misleading and unreliable

Primary cause of systematic underestimation of costs and overestimation of benefits is political-economic strategic misrepresentation driven by incentives to secure funding, not merely technical error or optimism bias
Interview and case-study evidence (UK and US studies) shows planners, officials, and consultants knowingly emphasize benefits and de-emphasize costs to pass approval and secure funding

Technical explanations and optimism bias alone do not fit the large-sample data: errors are systematically biased and have not improved over time, so intentional misrepresentation explains the patterns better

Reference class forecasting (outside view) method: (1) identify relevant reference class of past projects, (2) establish probability distribution for that class using empirical data, (3) position the specific project within that distribution to adjust forecasts

Reference class forecasting has been shown in practice to improve realism of cost estimates (example: Edinburgh Tram adjusted from 320m to 400m and has since been used for Crossrail and other projects)
When promoters do not prioritize accuracy, improved governance and accountability are required to change incentive structures and curb strategic misrepresentation

Governance reforms recommended: shift appraisals to neutral bodies, independent peer review, benchmarking, public disclosure and hearings, professional and criminal penalties for deceptive forecasts, require private cofinancing and shared financial responsibility, and stronger contract-writing capacity
Policy adoption evidence: UK Treasury guidance on optimism bias, Netherlands public hearings, legal actions like Boston Big Dig suits, and growing adoption by other governments and agencies
Current trends increase aggregate risk: a rapid stimulus-driven expansion of infrastructure spending, a geographic shift toward emerging economies, and rising incorporation of ICT into projects

Trend evidence: higher average overruns in emerging economies (rail overrun 64.6% vs 40.8% North America and 34.2% Europe) and numerous ICT-related failures and delays (Toll Collect, Heathrow Terminal 5, Hong Kong airport ICT problems)

Conclusion: To reduce waste and avoid financial and economic disasters in major infrastructure, planners must combine outside-view reference class forecasting with strengthened governance and accountability, especially given current stimulus, emerging market, and ICT risks
